members.name: Karlie Kloss
facts: Following her own curiosity, she took a coding class at the Flatiron School, which ignited a passion to see more people with the opportunity to make change using tech. She awarded 21 scholarships are awarded to young people in NYC to learn how to code.
In 2016, she launched Kode With Klossy summer coding camps, awarding 80+ scholarships across 3 camps in LA, NYC and St. Louis
She pivoted curricula, training and programs virtually in the midst of a global pandemic; creating a sustainable, accessible alternative for scholars

members.name: Ada Lovelace
facts: An English mathematician and writer, chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine.
She is often regarded as the first to recognize the full potential of a computing machine and the first computer programmer.
She was the first to recognize that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation, and created the first Algorithms.

members.name: Hedy Lamarr
facts: Co-inventor of frequency-hopping signal technology which prevents torpedo's radio guidance system from being tracked or jammed during WWII.
The frequency-hopping invention has been incorporated into modern-day bluetooth and GPS technologies.

members.name: Tester Figueroa
facts: TESTER Fact 1
TESTER Fact 2

members.name: Tester TORPEDOS
facts: TESTER Fact 1
TESTER Fact 2

members.name: Reed Hastings
facts: His first job was at Adaptive Technology, where he created a tool for debugging software.
In 1991, he founded his first company, Pure Software, which produced products to troubleshoot software.

In 1997, he co-founded Netflix, offering flat rate movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US by combining two emerging technologies; DVDs, which were much easier to send as mail than VHS-cassettes, and a website from which to order them, instead of a paper catalogue.

members.name: Marc Randolph
facts: A serial entrepreneur who is said to have helped found the U.S. edition of Macworld magazine and the Ordinal computer mail-order businesses MacWarehouse and MicroWarehouse.

In 1997, he co-founded Netflix, offering flat rate movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US by combining two emerging technologies; DVDs, which were much easier to send as mail than VHS-cassettes, and a website from which to order them, instead of a paper catalogue.
His fascination with using computer software to track customers' buying behavior would ultimately inform his decision to create a user interface at Netflix that doubled as a market research platform.

members.name: Rebecca Cherep de Guber
members.achievement: Pioneer in the development of CS in Argentina
facts: She was fundamental to the success of the early development of information science in Argentina.
co-founded a consultancy firm called Scientific Technical Advisors (ACT), in part to prevent the Institute's lines of research and work from being totally abandoned during Argentina's coup d'etat.

members.name: Cecilia Berdichevsky
facts: She was fundamental to the success of the early development of information science in Argentina.

members.name: Cicely Popplewell
members.altCareer: Advisor and administrator at the University of Manchester Computing Service
facts: Fundamental in designing the programming language for the Ferranti Mark 1.

members.name: Soledad Antelada Toledano
facts: The first female computer systems engineer and researcher in the cyber security division at Berkeley National Lab.
Founder of Girls Can Hack, an organization dedicated to engaging women in the cybersecurity field.

members.name: Ariel Lopez
facts: CEO of Knac, a skills platform that aims to reinvent the job application for professionals and companies.

members.name: Megan Smith
members.achievement: Chief Technology Officer of the United States
facts: The first female chief technology officer of the U.S. and served in the White House.
She promotes diversity throughout IT workplaces.

members.name: Adele Goldberg
members.achievement: Co-developer of the programming language Smalltalk-80
facts: Developed SIMULA 67 which is a programming setup that overlaps windows on graphic display screens.
Many of the concepts developed by her and her team at PARC became the basis for graphical user interfaces

members.name: George Antheill
facts: Co-inventor of frequency-hopping signal technology which prevents torpedo's radio guidance system from being tracked or jammed during WWII.
The frequency-hopping invention has been incorporated into modern-day bluetooth and GPS technologies.

members.name: Xuedong Huang
members.altCareer: Advocate of AI for Accessibility and AI for Cultural Heritage
facts: He modernized spoken language and integrative AI services via Azure AI
Microsoft Research recruited him to found and lead Microsoft's spoken language initiatives in 1993.

He helped Microsoft and Azure Cognitive Services achieve multiple industry's first human parity milestones on the following open research tasks: transcribing conversational speech, machine translation, conversational QnA,and c omputer vision image captioning.

members.name: Oliver Selfridge
facts: Pioneer of AI (artificial intelligence) and called the father of machine perception.
Helped organize the first ever public meeting on AI with Norbert Minsky in 1955.
Wrote important early papers on neural networks and pattern recognition and machine learning, and his Pandemonium paper (1959) is generally recognized as a classic in artificial intelligence.

members.name: Christopher Latham Scholes
facts: Inventor of the typewriter.
Inventor of the first QWERTY keyboard.

members.name: Lee McMahon
facts: He is best known for his contributions to early versions of the Unix operating system, in particular the sed stream editor.
Contributed to the development of comm, qsort (quicksort C library), grep, cref (Unix cross referencing function), cu, and Datakit (a virtual circuit switch developed at Bell Labs).
Created the McMahon system tournament, a tournament system for competitive games such as Chess and Go.

members.name: Kimberly Bryant
facts: Founder of Black Girls Code, an organization to teach programming to girls from underrepresented communities.

members.name: William English
facts: Known for his work int he development of the first computer mouse.
Key participant in The Mother of All Demos in 1964 that demonstrated the mouse and other technologies developed as part of the NLS (oN-Line System).
Developed a process to connect a terminal in the San Francisco Civic Auditorium to a host computer at SRI and transmit audio and video.

members.name: Evelyn Berezin
facts: Known for designing one of the first word processors in 1968.
In 1969, she founded the Redactron Corporation, which manufactured a word processing system called the Data Secretary.
She helped design the first computer reservation systems and computer data systems for banks.

members.name: Frederic Calland Williams
facts: Best known for his significant contribution to the development of Radar while working at the Telecommunications Research Establishment during World War II.
Designed the first stored-program digital computer, the SSEM (Small Scale Experimental Machine).
Recognized for the invention of an early memory device known as the Williams-Kilburn tube.

members.name: Jagadish Chandra Bose
members.altCareer: Botanist and Writer of Science Fiction
facts: He pioneered the investigation of radio and microwave optics
He was the first person from the Indian subcontinent to receive a US patent, in 1904.
He invented the crescograph.

members.name: Lois Haibt
facts: Known for being the only female member of the ten-person team at IBM that developed FORTRAN, the first successful high level programming language.

Her estimates of flow in high-traffic areas of the computer were obtained by calculating how often basic blocks of the program would execute. Haibt employed Monte Carlo methods (statistical analysis) for these calculations.
She created the first syntactic analyzer of arithmetic expressions.

members.name: Norman Nie
facts: Developed SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) to automate data analysis for manipulating data files, transforming data, and creating statistics on a mainframe computer.

He started the Stanford Institute for the Quantitative Study of Society (SIQSS), where he served as director. The Institute is devoted to the pursuit and sponsorship of high-quality empirical social science research about the nature of society and social change.

He co-founded the research firm Knowledge Networks(KN), which to this day is the only survey vendor to collect survey data over the Internet using probability samples, placing computers into homes that do not have Internet connectivity.

members.name: Owen Mock
facts: Computer software designer and programmer who pioneered computer operating systems in the 1950s.
He was part of a group of programmers at the Los Angeles division of NAA (North American Aviation) who developed the PACT series of compilers for the IBM 701 computer.
His group installed in the IBM 701 the North American 701 Monitor which was the first operating system to be in operation.

members.name: Paul Mockapetris
facts: Co-created the Internet DNS (Domain Name System).
Former program manager for networking at the ARPA (Advanced Research Projects Agency) of the U.S. Department of Defense.
He was Chief Scientist and chairman of the Board of IP address infrastructure software provider Nominum (1999 to 2016).

members.name: Jonathan Postel
facts: Co-created the Internet DNS (Domain Name System).
He made many significant contributions to the development of the Internet, particularly with respect to standards.
He is known principally for being the editor of the RFC (Request for Comments) document series, and for administering the IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority) until his death.

members.name: Peter Landin
facts: He was the first to realize that the lambda calculus could be used to model a programming language.
Responsible for inventing the SECD machine, the first abstract process virtual machine ever defined.
Invented the ISWIM programming language, defining the Landin off-side rule and for coining the term syntactic sugar.

members.name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
facts: He made significant contributions to Number Theory, a fundamental aspect of Computer Science

As late as 2012, researchers continued to discover that mere comments in his writings about simple properties and similar outputs for certain findings were themselves profound and subtle number theory results that remained unsuspected until nearly a century after his death.
His lost notebook, containing discoveries from the last year of his life, caused great excitement among mathematicians when it was rediscovered in 1976.

members.name: Håkon Wium Lie
facts: Best known for creating the concept and helping to develop CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) in 1994.
CTO (chief technology officer) of Opera Software from 1998 to 2016.

members.name: Brendan Eich
facts: Best known as the creator of the JavaScript programming language.
In early 1998, he co-founded the free and open-source software project Mozilla.
he designed the first SpiderMonkey engine for the Netscape Navigator browser at Netscape Communications.

members.name: Tim Berners Lee
members.achievement: Inventor of the World Wide Web
facts: Invented the WWW (World Wide Web).
Proposed HTML (Hypertext Markup Language).
Created the first website and web page.

members.name: Mitchel Resnick
members.achievement: LEGO Papert Professor of Learning Research
facts: His group has developed a new computer programming language, named Scratch, that makes it easier for children to create animated stories, video games, and interactive art.
He cofounded the Computer Clubhouse, an award-winning network of learning centers for youth from under-served communities.

His research group has developed a variety of educational tools that engage people in new types of design activities and learning experiences, including the Programmable Bricks that were the basis for the award-winning Lego Mindstorms and StarLogo software.

members.name: Yasmin Kafai
facts: She co-developed a new computer programming language, named Scratch, that makes it easier for children to create animated stories, video games, and interactive art.
Utilizing constructionist theory, Kafai examines technology designs and culture, and helped to set the foundation for programmatic initiatives on games and learning.
She advocates for the involvement of girls in gaming and programming.
She is an active voice on the impact of virtual gaming on real-life social behavior in youth.

members.name: Alexander Vazquez
facts: He co-founded CodePen, a useful and liberating online code editor for developers of any skill.
He does JavaScript development for CodePen, both front end and back, as well as Rails

members.name: Chris Coyier
facts: He co-founded CodePen, a useful and liberating online code editor for developers of any skill.
He is front-end developer and designer.
He writes a bunch of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for CodePen.

members.name: Martin Cooper
facts: He placed the first public call from a handheld portable cell phone while working at Motorola, from a Manhattan sidewalk to his counterpart at competitor Bell Labs.

Formulated the law which states that the maximum number of voice conversations or equivalent data transactions that can be conducted in all of the useful radio spectrum over a given area doubles every 30 months.

members.name: Seymour Aubrey Papert
members.achievement: Pioneer of AI and the Constructionist Movement
facts: He worked on learning theories, and was known for focusing on the impact of new technologies on learning in general, and in schools as learning organizations in particular.
He first used the term computational thinking in 1980 and again in 1996.

members.name: Jiro Kawakita
facts: Author of KJ method for organizing notes, also termed affinity walls in UX Research

members.name: David Axmark
facts: Co-created MySQL.
He co-founded MariaDB Foundation, the non-profit organisation charged with promoting, protecting and advancing the MariaDB codebase, community, and ecosystem.
He has been involved with free software since 1980 and has said he is committed to developing a successful business model using free open source software.

members.name: Ulf Michael Widenius
facts: He co-created MySQL.
He co-founded MariaDB Foundation, the non-profit organisation charged with promoting, protecting and advancing the MariaDB codebase, community, and ecosystem.

members.name: Allan Larsson
facts: He co-created MySQL.
He co-founded MariaDB Foundation, the non-profit organisation charged with promoting, protecting and advancing the MariaDB codebase, community, and ecosystem.

members.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
members.achievement: Refiner of the Binary Number System
facts: He invented the modern binary number system, the basis for binary code
He anticipated later developments in first-order predicate calculus, which were crucial for the theoretical foundations of computer science.

members.name: Kenneth Craik
facts: In 1943, he suggested that the mind constructs small-scale models of reality that it uses to anticipate events, which has led to Information Mapping
During WWII,he contributed to major advances on flight simulators for the RAF and did major studies on the effects of fatigue on pilots.

members.name: Guido van Rossum
facts: Best known as the author of the Python programming language.
He continues to oversee the Python development process, making decisions where necessary.

members.name: Albert Ronald da Silva Meyer
facts: Best known as the co-creator of LOOP programming language.
One of his seminal works introduced the concept of polynomial hierarchy.

members.name: Dennis M. Ritchie
facts: Best known as the creator of C Programming Language.
He is the co-creator of LOOP programming language.
He was one of the developers on the Unix operating system.

members.name: Larry Page
facts: Best known as the co-founder of the search engine Google.
He also pushed for keeping Google's home page famously sparse in its design because it would help the search results load faster.

When acquiring products and companies for Google, he asked whether the business acquisition passed the toothbrush test as an initial qualifier, asking the question: Is it something you will use once or twice a day, and does it make your life better?. This approach looked for usefulness above profitability, and long-term potential over near-term financial gain, which has been noted as rare in business acquiring processes.

members.name: Sergey Mikhailovich Brin
facts: Best known as the co-founder of the search engine Google.
His main focus during Google's early days was on developing data mining systems.
According to Forbes, he has donated over $1 billion to fund research on Parkinson's Disease.

members.name: Sir Anthony Hoare
facts: He was involved with developing international standards in programming and informatics, as a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP)
He is regretful about inventing the null reference

His most significant work includes Hoare logic, the formal language communicating sequential processes (CSP) used to specify the interactions between concurrent processes (and implemented in various programming languages such as occam).

members.name: Rasmus Lerdorf
facts: He co-authored and inspired the PHP scripting language, authoring the first two versions of the language and participating in the development of later versions.

He is a frequent speaker at Open Source conferences around the world. During his keynote presentation at OSCMS 2007, he presented a security vulnerability in each of the projects represented at the conference that year.

members.name: Pierre Omidyar
facts: In 1995, he began to write the original computer code for an online venue to enable the listing of a direct person-to-person auction for collectible items. He created a simple prototype on his web page.
In 2010, he launched an online investigative reporting news service, Honolulu Civil Beat, covering civic affairs in Hawaii.
In 2013, prompted by the Edward Snowden leaks, he announced the creation of the journalism venture First Look Media.

members.name: Edward Harry Friend
members.achievement: Earliest Describer of Bubble Sort Algorithms
facts: In a 1956 paper, he described a Sorting Exchange Algorithms.
His algorithm description would later be referred to as Bubble Sort.

members.name: John McCarthy
facts: Created the Lisp programming language family, influenced the design of the ALGOL programming language, and made timesharing popular.
He coined the term artificial intelligence, also known as AI.

members.name: Jean William Fritz Piaget
facts: He is considered the father of the constructivist view of learning.

members.name: Ben Schneiderman
facts: Conducted fundamental research in the field of human-computer interaction, developing new ideas, methods, and tools such as the direct manipulation interface, and his eight rules of design.

members.name: Ian Sommerville
facts: His research has included systems requirements engineering and system evolution.
Most widely read of his publications is probably his student text book Software Engineering, currently in its 10th edition.
He defined the process of Construction by configuration (CbC).
A major focus his work has been system dependability, including the use of social analysis techniques such as ethnography to better understand how people and computers deliver dependability.
